name: Highest common factor (HCF) Lowest common multiple (LCM) 1

skills.name: Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem
Identify common multiples of three or more numbers
Recognise when to find a multiple to solve a problem
Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem

explanations.A: Not quite. Remainders are the parts left over after a division, but we don't want anyone to be left out
explanations.B: Not quite. We are dividing the class, but what do we call the numbers that it can divide into exactly?
explanations.C: Not quite. The multiples are the numbers in that times table, e.g. 60, 120, 180 etc. We couldn't put that many people in each group as there are only 60 students
explanations.D: We need to know the numbers that we can divide 60 into exactly; these are the factors of 60

explanations.A: Not quite. The multiples are the numbers in that times table, e.g. 240, 480, 720 etc. We couldn't put that many stamps in each group as there are only 240 stamps
explanations.B: We need to know the numbers that we can divide 240 into exactly; these are the factors of 240
explanations.C: Not quite. Remainders are the parts left over after a division, but we don't want any stamps to be left out
explanations.D: Not quite. We are dividing the stamps, but what do we call the numbers that 240 can divide in to exactly?

explanations.A: It looks like you are thinking you have to divide a number into 15. If each class has 15 people, think about how you would work out more than one class.
explanations.B: It looks like you are thinking you have to divide a number into 15, which would give a fraction. If each class has 15 people, think about how you would work out more than one class.
explanations.C: A multiple of 15 is any value in the 15 times tables, so the total number of people will be 15 multiplied by the number of classes.
explanations.D: A factor is a number that divides into 15 equally. If one class has 15 people, think about how the number of people in a week will relate to 15.

explanations.A: A multiple of 60 is any value in the 60 times tables, so the total number of stamps will be 60 multiplied by the number of books.
explanations.B: A factor is a number that divides into 60 equally. If one book has 60 stamps, think about how the number of stamps in total will relate to 60
explanations.C: It looks like you are thinking you have to divide a number into 60. If each book has 60 stamps, think about how you would work out the total?
explanations.D: It looks like you are thinking you have to divide a number into 60. If each book has 60 stamps, think about how you would work out the total?

explanations.A: It looks like you've found a common factor of 4, 6 and 12.
explanations.B: A multiple of a number is a value in their times tables. So a common multiple of 4, 6 and 12 will be a value in the 4, 6 and 12 times tables, which is 12.
explanations.C: 18 is only a multiple of 6. Think about a multiple of 4 and 12 that is also a multiple of 6.
explanations.D: 20 is only a multiple of 4. Think about a multiple of 6 and 12 that is also a multiple of 4.

explanations.A: 15 is only a multiple of 3 and 15. Think about a multiple of 3, 6 and 15
explanations.B: 24 is only a multiple of 3 and 6. Think about a multiple of 3, 6 and 15
explanations.C: It looks like you've found a common factor of 3, 6 and 15
explanations.D: A multiple of a number is a value in their times tables. So a common multiple of 3, 6 and 15 will be a value in the 3, 6 and 15 times tables, which is 30.

explanations.A: The product means to multiply numbers together. 6 x 9 = 54. Will this be the first time these lights flash together?
explanations.B: The sum adds values together. 9 + 6 = 15. If one light flashes every 9 minutes, and the other every 6 minutes, will they flash at 15 seconds together?
explanations.C: To find out when the light flashes at the same time, count up in 6 and 9 until the numbers are the same. This is finding the lowest common multiple of 6 and 9.
explanations.D: The highest common factor will be a value smaller than 6 and 9.

explanations.A: To find out when the light flashes at the same time, count up in 12 and 8 until the numbers are the same. This is finding the lowest common multiple of 12 and 8.
explanations.B: The highest common factor will be a value smaller than 12 and 8.
explanations.C: The product means to multiply numbers together. 12 x 8 = 96. Will this be the first time these lights flash together?
explanations.D: The sum adds values together. 12+8 = 20. If one light flashes every 12 minutes, and the other every 8 minutes, will they flash at 20 seconds together?

explanations.A: The product means to multiply numbers together. 18 x 15. Will this give the smallest number of each packet to use?
explanations.B: The sum adds values together. To work out the number of each packet we need, we could try thinking about how many bread rolls there would be in 2 packets, 3 packets and so on. Could we get the same amount in packets of hot dogs. What are we finding here?
explanations.C: To find out how many of each item we are buying we would need to write out the multiples of 18 and 15. We want the smallest number that is in both of these times tables, which is the lowest common multiple.
explanations.D: Factors are numbers that divide the amount with no remainders. We need to buy whole packets so we wouldn't be splitting them up. Think about how many are in 1 packet, 2 packets etc. What are you finding here?

explanations.A: To find out how many of each item we are buying we would need to write out the multiples of 25 and 15. We want the smallest number that is in both of these times tables, which is the lowest common multiple.
explanations.B: Factors are numbers that divide the amount with no remainders. We need to buy whole packets so we wouldn't be splitting them up. Think about how many are in 1 packet, 2 packets etc. What are you finding here?
explanations.C: The product means to multiply numbers together. 15 x 25. Will this give the smallest number that we can buy?
explanations.D: The sum adds values together. To work out the number of each packet we need, we could try thinking about how many Swirlers there would be in 2 packets, 3 packets and so on. Could we get the same amount in packets of Fish-eyes?. What are we finding here?
